questions.text: Risk factors for primary open-angle glaucoma are all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Young age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Young age is not a risk factor for primary open-angle glaucoma, while family history, high myopia, and hypertension are.

questions.text: A patient developed diplopia after receiving blunt trauma to his right eye. The diplopia disappears if he closes either eye. The possible finding could be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lateral rectus paralysis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Binocular diplopia that disappears with either eye closed indicates an issue with eye alignment, often due to paralysis of one of the extraocular muscles, such as the lateral rectus muscle. alysis
  • ➤ alysis

questions.text: A mother takes her 8-month-old baby to her ophthalmologist. He has had a persistently watery eye since birth. Intermittently there is a yellow discharge surrounding the eye. The white of the eye has never been red. The baby is otherwise healthy. Examination reveals a white, quiet, normal eye. Slight pressure over the lacrimal sac produces a yellowish discharge from the normal puncta. What are the treatment option:

options.label: D
options.text: Take the child for Syringing and Probing Under GA

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Start Nasolacrimal duct massage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For congenital nasolacrimal duct obstruction in infants, initial treatment involves lacrimal sac massage (Crigler’s massage), typically sufficient to relieve the blockage in most cases.

questions.text: A young male of 22years present with gradual decrease of visual acuity in both eyes and change of refractive error. On examination with retinoscope there was high astigmatism. Give likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Keratoconus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In young adults with high astigmatism and progressive vision loss, keratoconus should be suspected. Diagnostic criteria include keratometry readings above 47 diopters, with readings over 50 diopters being definitive for keratoconus.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with increased VEGF?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Retinitis Pigmentosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Retinitis Pigmentosa is not associated with increased VEGF, unlike ischemic retinal conditions such as ROP, PDR, and CRVO, where VEGF levels are elevated due to retinal ischemia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the eye emergency department with sudden loss of vision in her right eye. She has noted increasing headache and her scalp is tender when she combs her hair. She complains of pain in the jaw when she eats, and tires easily. There is no ophthalmic history but she suffers from peptic ulceration. She takes no regular medications. There is no family history of medical problems. Examination reveals a visual acuity of counting fingers in the affected eye. A relative afferent pupillary defect is present. The optic disc appears slightly swollen. The left eye is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Giant Cell Arteritis (Temporal Arteritis)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant Cell Arteritis (Temporal Arteritis) is characterized by sudden vision loss, headache, scalp tenderness, and jaw claudication in older adults. It is an emergency and requires immediate corticosteroid treatment to prevent further vision loss.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with sudden onset of a drooping left eyelid. When he lifts the lid with his finger, he notices that he has double vision. He has a severe headache. He is otherwise fit and well with no past ophthalmic history. He is on no regular medication. There is no family history of medical problems. Examination reveals normal visual acuity in both eyes. A left ptosis is present. The left pupil is dilated. The left eye is abducted in the primary position of gaze. Testing eye movements reveals reduced adduction, elevation, and depression of the left eye. The remainder of the eye examination is normal. Identify the cranial nerve involved
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oculomotor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oculomotor nerve palsy is indicated by ptosis, a dilated pupil, and an eye in the "down and out" position. In cases with pupil involvement, consider a possible aneurysm, particularly in younger patients, and pursue further imaging. Microvascular causes (e.g., diabetes or hypertension) often spare the pupil.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 5-day history of sudden onset of floaters in the left eye accompanied by small flashes of light. His past medical history is significant for treated hypertension, and he has no other medical problems. Dilated funduscopy reveals no abnormalities, and visual acuity is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Posterior vitreous detachment (PVD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior vitreous detachment is indicated by floaters and flashes with a normal fundus and visual acuity. It is a benign condition but requires monitoring to rule out complications like retinal tears.

questions.text: The earliest symptom to occur in corneal ulcer is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pain is usually the earliest symptom in corneal ulcers, except in fungal ulcers, where pain may be less prominent and signs may be more evident than symptoms.

questions.text: Munson’s sign is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Keratoconus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Munson's sign is a diagnostic sign seen in advanced keratoconus, characterized by a protrusion of the lower eyelid when the patient looks downward due to the conical shape of the cornea.
  • ➤ Remember:
  • ➤ Remember:
  • ➤ In addition to Munson's sign, here are other signs commonly found in keratoconus:
  • ➤ In addition to Munson's sign,
  • ➤ other signs
  • ➤ keratoconus:
  • ➤ Vogt’s Striae: These are fine vertical stress lines seen in the posterior stroma of the cornea, typically in advanced keratoconus. They disappear when slight pressure is applied to the cornea. Fleischer’s Ring: This is an iron deposition ring seen around the base of the cone, typically appearing as a yellow-brown ring on slit-lamp examination. Scissoring Reflex: Also called the "scissor reflex" or "scissoring phenomenon," it is seen during retinoscopy. It occurs due to the irregular shape of the cornea, leading to multiple focal points. Oil Droplet Sign: This sign can be seen with direct ophthalmoscopy, where the distorted cornea produces an "oil droplet" appearance in the reflex. Rizzuti’s Sign: When a bright light is shone from the side of the eye, a conical reflection is observed on the nasal aspect of the cornea, indicating the conical shape characteristic of keratoconus . Pulsating Mires: On applanation tonometry, pulsating mires may be observed due to the irregular shape of the corneal surface in keratoconus. Topographic Signs: Corneal topography often reveals characteristic patterns, such as an inferior steepening or a "bow-tie" pattern, indicating the asymmetric steepening and thinning in keratoconus .
  • ➤ Vogt’s Striae: These are fine vertical stress lines seen in the posterior stroma of the cornea, typically in advanced keratoconus. They disappear when slight pressure is applied to the cornea.
  • ➤ Vogt’s Striae:
  • ➤ Fleischer’s Ring: This is an iron deposition ring seen around the base of the cone, typically appearing as a yellow-brown ring on slit-lamp examination.
  • ➤ Fleischer’s Ring:
  • ➤ Scissoring Reflex: Also called the "scissor reflex" or "scissoring phenomenon," it is seen during retinoscopy. It occurs due to the irregular shape of the cornea, leading to multiple focal points.
  • ➤ Scissoring Reflex:
  • ➤ Oil Droplet Sign: This sign can be seen with direct ophthalmoscopy, where the distorted cornea produces an "oil droplet" appearance in the reflex.
  • ➤ Oil Droplet Sign:
  • ➤ Rizzuti’s Sign: When a bright light is shone from the side of the eye, a conical reflection is observed on the nasal aspect of the cornea, indicating the conical shape characteristic of keratoconus .
  • ➤ Rizzuti’s Sign:
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Pulsating Mires: On applanation tonometry, pulsating mires may be observed due to the irregular shape of the corneal surface in keratoconus.
  • ➤ Pulsating Mires:
  • ➤ Topographic Signs: Corneal topography often reveals characteristic patterns, such as an inferior steepening or a "bow-tie" pattern, indicating the asymmetric steepening and thinning in keratoconus .
  • ➤ Topographic Signs:
  • ➤ .

questions.text: One of the following statements is true:

options.label: A
options.text: The most common cause of tractional retinal detachment is diabetic retinopathy

options.label: B
options.text: Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is always treated by surgery

options.label: C
options.text: The most common cause of Rhegmatogenous detachment is hypertension

options.label: D
options.text: In exudative retinal detachment, there are holes and tears in the retina

questions.correct_answer: A. The most common cause of tractional retinal detachment is diabetic retinopathy
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The most common cause of tractional retinal detachment is diabetic retinopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common cause of tractional retinal detachment is proliferative diabetic retinopathy, where fibrovascular tissue creates traction on the retina.

questions.text: The most visually disabling type of cataract is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Posterior sub capsular cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Posterior subcapsular cataract is the most visually disabling type of cataract due to its central location at the nodal point, directly impairing vision in conditions that require focused, central vision.
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ Additional Information:
  • ➤ PSC is often seen in "complicated cataracts," which can be remembered using the mnemonic TIGER :
  • ➤ TIGER
  • ➤ T umor I nflammation (chronic, such as uveitis) G laucoma (advanced cases) E ndocrine disorders (e.g., diabetes) R etinal diseases
  • ➤ T umor
  • ➤ T
  • ➤ I nflammation (chronic, such as uveitis)
  • ➤ I
  • ➤ G laucoma (advanced cases)
  • ➤ G
  • ➤ E ndocrine disorders (e.g., diabetes)
  • ➤ E
  • ➤ R etinal diseases
  • ➤ R
  • ➤ Another descriptive mnemonic for posterior subcapsular cataract characteristics is BAPP :
  • ➤ BAPP
  • ➤ B readcrumb appearance (small white opacities) A xial spread (central location affecting the visual axis) P osterior subcapsular position P olychromatic clusters (visible on slit-lamp examination)
  • ➤ B readcrumb appearance (small white opacities)
  • ➤ B
  • ➤ A xial spread (central location affecting the visual axis)
  • ➤ A
  • ➤ P osterior subcapsular position
  • ➤ P
  • ➤ P olychromatic clusters (visible on slit-lamp examination)
  • ➤ P

questions.text: At birth eye is usually:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypermetropic

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Newborns are usually hypermetropic due to their shorter axial length and flatter cornea. Emmetropia (normal vision) typically develops around 6 to 7 years of age as the eye matures.

questions.text: Clinically Significant Macular Edema includes all except:

options.label: A
options.text: Macular edema within 500 microns of foveola

options.label: B
options.text: Hard exudates within 500 microns of foveola

options.label: D
options.text: Macular edema larger than 1 disc diameter part of which is within 1 disc diameter of foveola

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neovascularization in fovea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clinically Significant Macular Edema includes macular edema and hard exudates near the foveola, as well as larger macular edema extending within 1 disc diameter of the foveola. Neovascularization in the fovea is not included in the CSME criteria.

questions.text: Synonym of zonular cataract:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lamellar cataract

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A zonular cataract is synonymous with a lamellar cataract, characterized by specific zonal opacities in the lens, often presenting as the most common visually significant congenital cataract with autosomal dominant inheritance.

questions.text: The theory that in accommodation the ciliary muscle contracts, relaxing the tension of the zonule of zinn:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Young-Helmholtz theory

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Young-Helmholtz theory describes accommodation as the process where the ciliary muscle contracts, relaxing the tension of the zonules, which allows the lens to become thicker and focus on nearby objects.

questions.text: Swimming pool conjunctivitis is caused by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chlamydia trachomatis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Swimming pool conjunctivitis is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D to K , also known as inclusion conjunctivitis, often linked to exposure in contaminated water settings.
  • ➤ Chlamydia trachomatis serotypes D to K

questions.text: In the log MAR chart, if a patient misses two letters of 0.8 line, the VA will be:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 0.84

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the log MAR chart, each missed letter adds 0.02 to the visual acuity score. For two missed letters on the 0.8 line, the resulting VA is 0.84 .
  • ➤ 0.84

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman attends the emergency department with nausea and vomiting. She says that her right eye is painful and red. Vision is reduced. She is longsighted and wears glasses for near and distance vision. She is generally fit. There is no family history of medical problems. On examination the emergency doctor finds the vision to be reduced to counting fingers in the right eye. The eye is red, the cornea appears cloudy and edematous, and the pupil is oval and dilated on the affected side. No view of the fundus is obtained. What are the immediate and definitive treatment options:

options.label: A
options.text: Topical pilocarpine and Nd:YAG laser capsulotomy

options.label: B
options.text: Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Femtosecond laser Iridotomy

options.label: C
options.text: Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Nd:YAG laser Iridotomy

questions.correct_answer: C. Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Nd:YAG laser Iridotomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Intravenous Acetazolamide, and Nd:YAG laser Iridotomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute angle-closure glaucoma, immediate treatment includes intravenous Acetazolamide for rapid IOP reduction, followed by Nd:laser iridotomy as the definitive treatment to relieve angle closure and prevent future episodes.
  • ➤ intravenous Acetazolamide
  • ➤ Nd:laser iridotomy

questions.text: The most likely diagnosis in a 25-year-old male / female having generalized restriction of eye movement in all the directions, intermittent ptosis, proximal muscle weakness, fatigability. The most useful test is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Edrophonium test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with symptoms suggestive of myasthenia gravis, the Edrophonium (Tensilon) test is the most useful and specific initial diagnostic test, as it can quickly confirm the presence of myasthenia gravis by temporarily improving muscle weakness.
  • ➤ Edrophonium (Tensilon) test

questions.text: In the grading of Trachoma, Trachomatous Inflammation-follicular is defined as the presence of:

options.label: A
options.text: Five or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva

options.label: B
options.text: Three or more follicles in the lower tarsal conjunctiva

options.label: C
options.text: Five or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva

options.label: D
options.text: Three or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva

questions.correct_answer: C. Five or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Five or more follicles in the upper tarsal conjunctiva

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trachomatous Inflammation-Follicular (TF) is defined by the presence of five or more follicles, each ≥0.1 mm in diameter, on the upper tarsal conjunctiva according to WHO’s grading of trachoma.
  • ➤ five or more follicles, each ≥0.1 mm in diameter, on the upper tarsal conjunctiva

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with bilateral proptosis, lid retraction, and periorbital edema. Thyroid function tests reveal the following values: TSH (Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone) <0.01 mIU/L (normal range: 0.4-4.0 mIU/L), free T4 (thyroxine) 4.5 ng/dL (normal range: 0.8-1.8 ng/dL), and free T3 (triiodothyronine) 9.2 pg/mL (normal range: 2.3-4.2 pg/mL). An ophthalmic evaluation is performed. Which of the following findings, in conjunction with the clinical and laboratory data, is not typically associated with thyroid eye disease in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Choroidal neovascular membrane (CNVM) is not associated with thyroid eye disease. In TED, common findings include proptosis, restrictive myopathy, and occasionally optic disc swelling, due to autoimmune inflammation of orbital tissues and extraocular muscles.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of itching, redness, and mucous discharge from both eyes, particularly during the spring and summer months. On examination, you observe the presence of giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What type of immunologic reaction is most likely involved in the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Type 1 Hypersensitivity Reaction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC) is primarily a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction, leading to the development of giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva and other symptoms, often triggered by seasonal allergens.

questions.text: A 30-year-old builder was using a hammer to hit a steel chisel. He felt something hit his eye and the vision became blurred. He is fit and well and there is no history of medical problems. On examination, vision was reduced to 6/12. A fluorescein staining lesion was seen on the cornea but this appeared Seidel-negative. A small hyphema was seen in the anterior chamber, and in the red reflex observed with a direct ophthalmoscope a well delineated lens opacity was seen. The retina appeared normal. All of these diagnostic tests are useful in evaluating the patient except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected intraocular metallic foreign bodies, MRI should be avoided due to the risk posed by magnetic fields , which can move metal fragments and cause further injury.
  • ➤ MRI should be avoided due to the risk posed by magnetic fields

questions.text: While working in the laboratory, a colleague inadvertently sprays his eyes with an alkali solution. What is the immediate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Cover the eyes with sterile gauze and seek medical attention immediately.

options.label: B
options.text: Rinse the eyes with sterile saline solution for 2 minutes and then seek medical attention.

options.label: C
options.text: Irrigate the eyes with copious amounts of water for at least 15-30 minutes and then seek medical attention.

options.label: D
options.text: Administer antibiotic eye drops immediately to prevent infection.

questions.correct_answer: C. Irrigate the eyes with copious amounts of water for at least 15-30 minutes and then seek medical attention.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Irrigate the eyes with copious amounts of water for at least 15-30 minutes and then seek medical attention.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of eye exposure to alkali substances, immediate and prolonged irrigation with water or an isotonic solution for at least 15 to 30 minutes is essential. Neutralizing agents should never be used, and double aversion of the upper eyelid can help remove any residual chemical.

questions.text: The corneal endothelium is best examined by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Specular microscope

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The specular microscope is the most effective instrument for examining the corneal endothelium, allowing for the assessment of cell count, cell shape (hexagonality), and overall health , which is essential for maintaining corneal clarity and preventing edema.
  • ➤ specular microscope
  • ➤ cell count, cell shape (hexagonality), and overall health

questions.text: For every 100,000 population, the highest prevalence of blindness in the world is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sub-Saharan Africa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The highest prevalence of blindness per 100,000 population is seen in Sub-Saharan Africa , primarily due to limited healthcare access and high rates of preventable causes of blindness.
  • ➤ Sub-Saharan Africa

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a mildly painful red eye and blurred vision. She underwent a corneal graft one year ago. She is otherwise healthy and on no current medications. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Topical corticosteroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected corneal graft rejection, the immediate treatment of choice is topical corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and prevent graft failure. Look for signs like the Khodadoust line and Krachmer spots as indicators of rejection.

questions.text: All of the following conditions are contraindicated or likely to worsen in a case of primary open angle glaucoma, when treated with Timolol maleate 0.5% eye drops except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypertension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Timolol maleate 0.5% eye drops should be used cautiously or avoided in patients with hypercholesterolemia, depression, and asthma. However, it is not contraindicated in hypertension and may even help manage high blood pressure.

questions.text: Adhesion of margins of two eyelids is called
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ankyloblepharon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankyloblepharon is the adhesion or fusion of the upper and lower eyelid margins, preventing normal eyelid separation. This is distinct from symblepharon, which involves adhesion of the eyelid to the eyeball.

questions.text: Which of the rectus muscles inserts the closes to the limbus?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Medial Rectus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The medial rectus muscle inserts closest to the limbus , following the mnemonic MILS (Medial, Inferior, Lateral, Superior) for the order of rectus muscle insertion distances.
  • ➤ medial rectus muscle inserts closest to the limbus
  • ➤ MILS

questions.text: The distance between the macula and the disc is ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 mm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The macula is located about 3 mm (or two disc diameters) away from the optic disc and lies temporally to the optic disc, with the fovea positioned half a disc diameter below the optic disc center.

questions.text: Horner's syndrome is characterized by all of the following except ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cycloplegia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Horner's syndrome is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis , but cycloplegia is not a feature of this syndrome.
  • ➤ ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis
  • ➤ cycloplegia is not a feature

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a 15-year history of poorly controlled type 2 diabetes presents to the ophthalmology clinic for a routine eye examination. He reports mild blurring of vision over the past few months but denies any pain or sudden vision loss. On fundoscopic examination, you observe multiple cotton wool spots along with microaneurysms and mild retinal hemorrhages. What is the most likely cause of the cotton wool spots in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Retinal ischemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cotton wool spots on fundoscopic examination indicate retinal ischemia, often seen in diabetic retinopathy due to chronic hyperglycemia-related microvascular damage. These are also referred to as "soft exudates" and are distinct from hard exudates, which are associated with lipid deposits.

questions.text: All of the following are responsible for blindness in childhood except ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dacryocystitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While glaucoma, malnutrition, and ophthalmia neonatorum are recognized causes of childhood blindness, dacryocystitis is not typically associated with blindness in children.

questions.text: No. of doses for treatment of Vitamin A deficiency is
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 3 doses

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of Vitamin A deficiency consists of three doses given at 0, 1, and 14 days, with specific IU dosages based on age, to ensure effective replenishment and prevent deficiency-related complications.
  • ➤ three doses

questions.text: Consider the following sites of lesion in brain: 1.⁠ ⁠Lateral geniculate body 2.⁠ ⁠Optic radiation 3.⁠ ⁠Optic tract 4.⁠ ⁠Optic chiasma Which of the above can result in homonymous hemianopia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Homonymous hemianopia occurs due to lesions in the visual pathway beyond the optic chiasma, specifically in the lateral geniculate body, optic tract, or optic radiation. The optic chiasma, in contrast, results in heteronymous visual field defects, such as bitemporal hemianopia.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with a painful, red right eye and blurred vision over the last two days. He wears soft contact lenses, and contact lens tolerance has decreased in recent days. On examination, vision is reduced to 6/60 in the right eye, conjunctiva is inflamed, and there is a central opacity on the cornea along with a small hypopyon. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bacterial keratitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bacterial keratitis is a serious infection commonly associated with contact lens use, especially when hygiene is compromised. Symptoms include pain, redness, blurred vision, corneal opacity, and potentially a hypopyon. Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a frequent cause of bacterial keratitis in contact lens users.

questions.text: Weakness of both Adduction and Abduction is seen in ?

options.label: D
options.text: Its Common feature in all 3 types

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Duane’s Retraction syndrome Type 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Duane’s Retraction Syndrome Type 3, there is weakness in both adduction and abduction, resulting in restricted horizontal movement. A common feature across all types of DRS is globe retraction on attempted adduction, where the eyeball retracts into the orbit.

questions.text: Ophthalmoplegic migraine means:

options.label: A
options.text: When headache is followed by complete paralysis of the llIrd and Vith nerve on the same side as the hemicrania

options.label: B
options.text: When the headache is followed by partial paralysis of the IIIrd nerve on the same side as the hemicrania without any scotoma

options.label: C
options.text: Headache is associated with IlIrd, 4th and VI th nerve paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Headache is associated with optic neuritis

questions.correct_answer: B. When the headache is followed by partial paralysis of the IIIrd nerve on the same side as the hemicrania without any scotoma
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) When the headache is followed by partial paralysis of the IlIrd nerve on the same side as the hemicrania without any scotoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ophthalmoplegic migraine is characterized by headache followed by partial paralysis of the IIIrd cranial nerve on the same side, typically without visual scotomas, and usually resolves spontaneously after the headache subsides.
  • ➤ headache followed by partial paralysis of the IIIrd cranial nerve

questions.text: Enucleation of the eyeball is contraindicated in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Panophthalmitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enucleation is contraindicated in panophthalmitis due to the risk of infection spread to the CSF and meninges. Instead, evisceration with antibiotic lavage is the safer procedure in such cases.
  • ➤ Enucleation is contraindicated in panophthalmitis

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about pthisis bulbi:

options.label: B
options.text: Calcification of the lens is common

options.label: D
options.text: Size of the globe is reduced

questions.correct_answer: A. The intraocular pressure is increased
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) The intraocular pressure is increased

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pthisis bulbi is a condition characterized by a shrunken, malformed eye with decreased intraocular pressure due to ciliary body shutdown.
  • ➤ decreased intraocular pressure

questions.text: Which one of the following stromal dystrophy is a recessive condition:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Macular dystrophy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Macular dystrophy is the only autosomal recessive stromal corneal dystrophy, and it is marked by mucopolysaccharide deposits within the corneal stroma.

questions.text: Surface ectoderm gives rise to all of the following structures except ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anterior layer of iris

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The surface ectoderm gives rise to external eye structures like the lens, corneal epithelium, and conjunctival epithelium, while the anterior layer of the iris is derived from the neural ectoderm.
  • ➤ Mnemonic for neural crest derivatives: “CREST”
  • ➤ neural crest
  • ➤ “CREST”
  • ➤ C : Corneal endothelium R : Retina E : Endothelium of cornea S : Stroma (of cornea) and Sclera T : Trabecular meshwork
  • ➤ C : Corneal endothelium
  • ➤ C
  • ➤ R : Retina
  • ➤ R
  • ➤ E : Endothelium of cornea
  • ➤ E
  • ➤ S : Stroma (of cornea) and Sclera
  • ➤ S
  • ➤ T : Trabecular meshwork
  • ➤ T

questions.text: Tylosis refers to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypertrophied drooping lid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tylosis refers to a thickened, drooping eyelid, which can impact eyelid function and appearance.

questions.text: A 79-year-old man presents with a lesion on his right lower lid. It has been there for some months and has gradually grown bigger. It is ulcerated, and the ulcer shows a pearly margin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Basal cell carcinoma is the most common eyelid cancer, especially in older individuals, often presenting as a slow-growing lesion with ulceration and a characteristic pearly border.

questions.text: Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is characterized by
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neovascularization

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neovascularization is the hallmark of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR), distinguishing it from non-proliferative stages. This abnormal vessel growth is a response to retinal ischemia and can lead to serious vision complications if untreated.

questions.text: A 26-year-old lady presents with a 3-day history of blurring of vision in the right eye. This has become progressively worse. She also has pain caused by moving the eye. She has previously had an episode of weakness in the right arm 2 years ago, but this settled without treatment. She otherwise fit and well. On examination the vision was 6/60, with no improvement on looking through a pinhole. A central scotoma was present on confrontation. The eye was white and quiet with no abnormality noted except for a right relative afferent pupillary defect. Which of the following is next immediate step in management:

options.label: A
options.text: Intravenous methylprednisolone for 3-5 days followed by an oral prednisone taper

options.label: D
options.text: Immediate MRI of the brain and orbits with gadolinium

questions.correct_answer: A. Intravenous methylprednisolone for 3-5 days followed by an oral prednisone taper
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)⁠ ⁠Intravenous methylprednisolone for 3–5 days followed by an oral prednisone taper

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In acute optic neuritis, particularly with significant vision loss and symptoms like pain with eye movement, the immediate management involves high-dose intravenous methylprednisolone, followed by a course of oral prednisone.

questions.text: Staphylococcus is associated with all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) VKC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphylococcus is commonly associated with conditions like phlyctenulosis, styes, and bacterial conjunctivitis, but not with Vernal Keratoconjunctivitis (VKC), which is an allergic condition.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy came to consult you in your OPD where he gave history of trauma to his right eye. On carrying out slit-lamp examination you see a superficial injury on the cornea. Usually, in injuries involving only the corneal epithelium, the stratified squamous epithelium rapidly regenerates because of the presence of stem cells. Where are the Palisades of Vogt containing the stem cells located?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Limbus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Palisades of Vogt , located at the limbus, contain stem cells essential for the regeneration of the corneal epithelium. This limbal stem cell activity is crucial for healing superficial corneal injuries and maintaining corneal clarity.
  • ➤ Palisades of Vogt

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with blurred vision and discomfort in both eyes. He has a history of poorly controlled diabetes and hypertension. On examination, his intraocular pressure (IOP) is elevated, and slit-lamp evaluation reveals signs of neovascularization of the iris (NVI) in both eyes. The fundus examination shows widespread retinal ischemia, and fluorescein angiography confirms retinal non-perfusion. The ophthalmologist diagnoses the patient with neovascular glaucoma secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Which laser procedure is most appropriate to treat the underlying cause of this patient’s iris neovascularization?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Panretinal photocoagulation (PRP)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of neovascular glaucoma secondary to proliferative diabetic retinopathy, panretinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the primary treatment to reduce retinal ischemia and lower VEGF production, thereby addressing the root cause of neovascularization.
  • ➤ panretinal photocoagulation (PRP)

questions.text: A 35 year-old man presents to his family doctor with erythematous, swollen right upper and lower eyelids, worsening over the previous 2 days. He is unable to open them. He feels unwell and has a temperature. Examination reveals marked lid swelling, a tender globe and, on manual opening of the lids, a proptosis with chemotic injected conjunctiva. Eye movements are limited in all directions. Visual acuity and color vision are normal, and there is no relative afferent pupillary defect. The optic disc and retina also appear normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Orbital Cellulitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orbital cellulitis presents with erythematous swollen eyelids, proptosis, limited eye movements, tenderness, and systemic symptoms such as fever. In contrast, preseptal cellulitis does not typically involve proptosis or restricted eye movements, and thyroid eye disease presents more gradually and without systemic symptoms.

questions.text: Which lesion of the visual pathways produces a macular sparing field defect?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Macular sparing field defects are associated with occipital lobe lesions due to the dual blood supply of the macula from both the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) and, to some extent, the middle cerebral artery (MCA). This feature can help localize a lesion specifically to the occipital cortex in cases of homonymous visual field loss.

questions.text: A child with history of malnutrition is examined and the following finding is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anterior staphyloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anterior staphyloma is a severe complication of corneal ulceration, often associated with malnutrition, particularly vitamin A deficiency. It is characterized by protrusion of the outer coat of the eye, involving the cornea and sclera, with underlying uveal tissue.

questions.text: Which of the following cylindrical lens combinations can be used to cure astigmatism that follows the rule?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) -3.00 DC x 180, +1.00 DC x 90

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ With-the-rule astigmatism correction typically requires a negative cylindrical lens power at 180 degrees and a positive cylindrical lens power at 90 degrees to compensate for the natural curvature of the cornea.

questions.text: Substance deposited in Band Shaped Keratopathy is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) calcium phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Band Shaped Keratopathy involves the deposition of calcium phosphate in the cornea, often presenting as a horizontal band across the eye. This deposition can be related to chronic eye inflammation or systemic calcium imbalances.
  • ➤ calcium phosphate

questions.text: Which of the following is not a type of surgery done for the condition shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kuhnt surgery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Quickert, Lateral Tarsal Split, and Wheeler procedures are used for entropion correction, while the Kuhnt-Szymanowski procedure is used for ectropion correction and is therefore not suitable for the condition shown in the image.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman was admitted to the oncology department for management of breast cancer which metastases to the brain. A week after her admission she started experiencing sudden painless loss of vision. After evaluation by the doctors, she is found to have an exudative retinal detachment. Which of the following is not a cause of exudative retinal detachment?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diabetic retinopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diabetic retinopathy is primarily associated with tractional or mixed retinal detachment rather than exudative retinal detachment. Exudative RD is typically caused by conditions like toxemia of pregnancy, posterior scleritis, and malignant hypertension that lead to vascular or inflammatory changes.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented with a complaint of diplopia following head trauma. He had a transient loss of consciousness and started experiencing diplopia immediately upon awakening. He presented to the hospital for evaluation. Cranial nerve examination revealed 4th nerve palsy. The features that can be seen in this patient is:
questions.correct_answer: C. Hypertropia of the affected eye
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypertropia of the affected eye

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In fourth nerve palsy, hypertropia of the affected eye is observed due to superior oblique muscle paralysis. Patients often adopt a contralateral head tilt to minimize double vision.

questions.text: In which of the following uveitic conditions is it contraindicated to put in an intraocular lens after cataract surgery
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intraocular lens implantation after cataract surgery is contraindicated in patients with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis due to the high risk of intense postoperative uveitis and inflammatory complications.
  • ➤ juvenile rheumatoid arthritis

questions.text: Which anti-TB drug causes red colour vision defects or optic neuropathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethambutol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethambutol toxicity can lead to red-green color vision defects and optic neuropathy. Regular monitoring of visual function, especially color vision, is essential when patients are on ethambutol therapy to prevent irreversible damage.

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Lim’s forceps

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lim’s forceps is a toothed forceps used to stabilize the globe during ocular surgeries and is also used in the Forced Duction Test to differentiate between restrictive and paralytic squint.

questions.text: Conditions causing large pupils are all except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Horner’s Syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Horner's syndrome is associated with a constricted (small) pupil, while other conditions, such as sympathomimetic drug use, alcohol, and Holmes-Adie syndrome, can cause pupil dilation (large pupils).

questions.text: Fluorescein staining would be most useful in
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Contact lens fitting

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fluorescein staining is most useful for assessing the fit of rigid gas-permeable (RGP) contact lenses, where it helps visualize the tear film pattern and ensure proper lens fitting.

questions.text: Atropine eyedrop is contraindicated in
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Acute congestive glaucoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atropine eye drops are contraindicated in acute congestive glaucoma because they increase intraocular pressure, worsening the condition.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions Berlin's edema is seen ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) After concussional trauma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Berlin's edema, also known as commotio retinae, is a retinal condition seen following blunt trauma to the eye.

questions.text: The fastest acting cycloplegic drug is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tropicamide is the fastest acting and shortest duration cycloplegic drug, commonly used in outpatient eye exams for quick pupil dilation.

questions.text: Which of the following statement is true regarding Acanthamoeba keratitis?

options.label: A
options.text: For the isolation of the causative agent, corneal scraping should be cultured on a nutrient

options.label: B
options.text: The causative agent, Acanthamoeba is a helminth whose normal habitat is soil

options.label: C
options.text: Keratitis due to Acanthamoeba is not seen in the immunocompromised host

options.label: D
options.text: Acanthamoeba does not depend upon a human host for the completion of its life-cycle

questions.correct_answer: D. Acanthamoeba does not depend upon a human host for the completion of its life-cycle
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acanthamoeba does not depend upon a human host for the completion of its life-cycle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acanthamoeba does not rely on a human host to complete its life cycle and can thrive independently in environmental sources such as fresh water.

questions.text: A person has restricted eye movements in all directions, ptosis with no squint or diplopia. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Myasthenia gravis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myasthenia gravis is suggested by restricted eye movements and ptosis without squint or diplopia, due to the characteristic involvement of ocular muscles in this neuromuscular disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is contraindicated in patients with allergy to sulphonamides ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Brinzolamide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brinzolamide (and other similar carbonic anhydrase inhibitors like dorzolamide) is contraindicated in patients with a sulfonamide allergy due to the risk of cross-reactivity.

questions.text: Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) is responsible for which type of visual field defect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Central

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD) causes a central visual field defect due to macular damage, with peripheral vision generally remaining unaffected.

questions.text: Typically bilateral inferior lens subluxation of the lens is seen in ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Homocystinuria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilateral inferior lens subluxation is characteristic of homocystinuria, whereas Marfan's syndrome commonly results in superotemporal (upward and outward) displacement of the lens.
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Note:
  • ➤ Sulfite oxidase deficiency is a rare cause of lens subluxation.

questions.text: Mass Treatment of trachoma is undertaken, when the prevalence is more than
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 10%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mass treatment for trachoma is initiated when the prevalence of active cases is over 10%, following WHO guidelines.

questions.text: In fluorescein angiography dye is injected into
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Antecubital vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In fluorescein angiography, the dye is injected into the antecubital vein, allowing it to circulate systemically to the retinal vessels, where it highlights any abnormalities in the vasculature.

questions.text: Which of the following accurately pairs the diagnostic stain with the corneal condition it indicates?

options.label: A
options.text: Cobalt blue with trypan blue for corneal ulcer

options.label: B
options.text: Cobalt green with Rose Bengal stain for corneal opacity

options.label: C
options.text: Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer

options.label: D
options.text: Cobalt blue with lissamine green for corneal abrasion

questions.correct_answer: C. Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cobalt blue with fluorescein stain for corneal ulcer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cobalt blue light with fluorescein stain is the diagnostic technique of choice for detecting corneal ulcers, as it highlights epithelial defects by producing a green fluorescence.
